image:image.image:title: PollenImage
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. That's really a lot of pollen. A lot of pollen. Image by Brooke Novak

image:image.image:title: Waynesboro_Outlet_Village_Building_7_after_fire
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. You don't like prescribed burns? Why not? Image from Wikimedia commons.

image:image.image:title: Wildfire_in_the_Pacific_Northwest
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Wildfires burn in the Pacific Northwest, even with its reputation as a wet region. In the past, as today, humans likely played a role, along with climate. Image from Wikimedia Commons.

image:image.image:title: FirstClass
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Your presentation will go better when you fly in style. Photo credit:

image:image.image:title: unformattedcodeblock
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. When code looks crummy it's not usable. This has since been fixed.

image:image.image:title: RPackrat
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Neotoma and R together at last!

image:image.image:title: Network_ORCiD
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. A second order co-author network generated using R and ORCiD's public API.

image:image.image:title: DCFC0002.JPG
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Dark data. There is likely some excellent data down this pathway, but it's too spooky for me to want to access it, let's just ignore it for now. Photo Credit: J. Illingworth.
Figure 1. PaleoDeepDive body size estimates generated from a publication corpus (gray bars) versus estimates directly assimilated and entered by humans. Results are not significantly different.

image:image.image:title: Sound_mixer_2
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Mixer is a ubiquitous feature of academia's social scene, but they can be complicated for a number of reasons. Photo Credit: Fotokannan, via Wikipedia.

image:image.image:title: Fig1_UMLDiagram
image:image.image:caption: A flowchart showing the relationships between classes in the neotoma package.

image:image.image:title: PeeWeeBiker
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. This is what coding machismo looks like on me.

image:image.image:title: 800px-Clams_casino
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Why is there a picture of clams with bacon on them associated with this blog post? Credit: Sheri Wetherell (click image for link)

image:image.image:title: Moss-Racusin_GenderPerception
image:image.image:caption: If you aren't aware of this figure by now you should be. Credit: Moss-Racusin et al. 2012.

image:image.image:title: gsa-logo_14C_transp
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. GSA 2014 in beautiful downtown Vancouver! I listened to them building this convention center every day for months on end, so it had better look nice!

image:image.image:title: 256px-Sunset_Marina
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Hoping we'll find a proxy for beautiful sunsets. Image from: BrendelSignature at en.wikipedia

image:image.image:title: Figure 1. Paleo-lake level reconstruction in the Melas Baisn of Mars. From Williams and Weitz (2014).
Deevey_diagram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The first pollen diagram for the northeastern United States, published by Edward Deevey in 1939. It also looks like an early use of Comic Sans.

image:image.image:title: -Citation_needed-
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Citations are important, but they're rarely used in an impartial manner. (image source: wikipedia)

image:image.image:title: Unabomber
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Heartland's funders did not particularly like the comparison between climate science and the Unabomber. (image source: wikipedia)

image:image.image:title: Five_Myr_Climate_Change
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Does showing climate has changed in the past prove that climate change is natural?

image:image.image:title: HayfeverImage
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Your pain is science's gain. Pollen may go into your nose, but it also enters aquatic environments where it is preserved in lake sediments. Photo Credit: flickr/missrogue

image:image.image:title: journal.pone.0053139.g002
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. From Walzer et al. (2013), protected area management must include consideration of natural and management best practices, while considering the needs of the public. Each of these may at times be at odds with one another, and so interdisciplinary research into each context is required.

image:image.image:title: 1280px-Thousand_Islands_2
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Parks close to urban centers, like Thousand Islands National Park act as refuges for species at risk, and provide connectivity to help support shifting ranges associated with climate change.

image:image.image:title: BrowneHenriette_-_A_Girl_Writing;_The_Pet_Goldfinch
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. If you want to be a PI you'd best spend more time writing, and less time watching birds. "A Girl Writing; The Pet Goldfinch" Henriette Browne (1870)

image:image.image:title: ScienceHall_Dangerfield
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. That time that Science Hall was in a very famous movie.

image:image.image:title: IMG_20140408_173235
image:image.image:caption: The Botanic Gardens in the 5th Arrondissment just before a storm blows over them.

image:image.image:title: L500xH329_jpg_BATIMENT_A5_A075A1144-424e3
image:image.image:caption: Fig 1. Lots of hallways to get lost in.

image:image.image:title: labos-2012
image:image.image:caption: The location and number of CNRS Labs, from the CNRS website.

image:image.image:title: ChapterVII_rose
image:image.image:caption: The most beautiful rose on Asteroid B-612. One of a set of species described from only a single specimen.

image:image.image:title: FirstHouseMilwaukee_1840s
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Martin Stein's house was the only Euro-American home in the Milwaukee area until at least the 1840s (image from the Wisconsin Historical Archives).

image:image.image:title: MacrosystemsRewards
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Interdisciplinary research requires effort in a number of different areas, and these efforts are not recognized under traditional reward structures.

image:image.image:title: MacrosystemsAmazon
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Heffernan et al. (2014), multiple scales and disciplines interact to explain patterns of change in the Amazon basin.

image:image.image:title: no_update_chonology
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. This chronology depends on only three control points and assumes constant sedimentation from 7000 years before present to the modern. No matter how you re-build this age model it's going to underestimate uncertainty in this region.

image:image.image:title: calib
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. A radiocarbon age estimate (in 14C years; the pink, normally distributed curve) intercepts the IntCal curve (blue ribbon). The probability density associated with this intercept builds the age estimate for that sample, in calendar years.

image:image.image:title: AMSshorts1
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The accelerator in Belfast uses massive magnets to accelerate Carbon particles to 5 million km/h.

image:image.image:title: ggplot_naturalEarth
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Here's an amazing background for your maps using Natural Earth Data and ggplot2

image:image.image:title: 6480160001_e89794980d
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Another option for self-promotion, unfortunately MySpace just isn't cool anymore.

image:image.image:title: Kheops-Pyramid
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The reality of blogging (totally not based on my own experience).

image:image.image:title: GitInPane
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. You should see a tab called "Git" in your workspace pane (top right pane in the RStudio window).

image:image.image:title: GitHub_GUI_screenshot
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. When you open up the GitHub GUI you should see the repositories you are associated with (Column 1), local repositories (Column 2) and the contents of readme files for any selected repositories (Column 3).

image:image.image:title: SignificantCores
image:image.image:caption: A number of pollen records in British Columbia show significant changes in pollen richness during the Holocene (calibrated years BP on the x-axis, pollen richness on the y-axis).

image:image.image:title: SignificantCores
image:image.image:caption: A number of pollen records in British Columbia show significant changes in pollen richness during the Holocene (calibrated years BP on the x-axis, pollen richness on the y-axis).

image:image.image:title: joe_small
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. This is not what you want to have happen in a phone interview. Remove all sharp objects & rodents from the room when you take the call.

image:image.image:title: Fig5_redux
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5 from Goring et al., the relationships between plant richness and smoothed pollen richness and vice versa both show a slightly negative relationship (accounting for very little variability), meaning higher plant richness is associated with lower pollen richness.

image:image.image:title: pubbyyear
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The distribution of publication years in the Neotoma database.

image:image.image:title: LGMplot
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The distribution of pollen sample sites with Spruce pollen dating from the Last Glacial Maximim, 21,000 years ago (21ka),

image:image.image:title: ngeo1797-f1
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Sources of paleoclimate reconstruction from the PAGES 2K network.

image:image.image:title: camelhumps
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. A camel with many humps. Probably a relative of Alice's given genetics and whatnot. (Credit: flickr user bristley)

image:image.image:title: Goringetal2009_undersampling
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Undersampled climate space in British Columbia with respect to the BC Modern Pollen Database. The regions that are undersampled (darker) are not the regions that are spatially undersampled because of high regional climatic heterogeneity.

image:image.image:title: 320px-Daphnia_magna
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Cladoceran Daphnia. Cladocerans may more broadly be useful for climate reconstruction if the results of a new study hold.

image:image.image:title: FortLocations
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Even across relatively small spatial scales there is a tremendous amount of data available for analysis. These points represent the locations of US Historic Climatology Network sites (blue dots) and 19th Century Fort and Observer climate records (red).

image:image.image:title: Figure1.DataSummary
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The shaded parts of Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan are my study region. They will be the focus of my talk.

image:image.image:title: PublicationNetwork
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. My publication network. I am the dot in the center, collaborators are linked by lines based on co-authorship. The plot is coded using R. Code used is included here.

image:image.image:title: JacksonSites
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Location of the new core sites and surrounding records with pollen data from the period between 50kyr and 13kyr. This image comes from the Neotoma database.

image:image.image:title: NoAnalogueLiuetal
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Squared chord distances reported for Anderson Lake and Jackson Pond in Liu et al., 2013.

image:image.image:title: StemDensity
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. This was the inspiration for Figure 1.

image:image.image:title: IMG_8419
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Pre-settlement stem density in the US Midwest based on Public Land Survey data. Dark green is highest stem density, yellow is prairie, and white and red are regions outside the domain.

image:image.image:title: GoringFiveYearFlow
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. A five-year research plan, showing proposed products from a focused research program, with a concentration on the Pacific Northwest.

image:image.image:title: IBS Logo
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The International Biogeography Society is worth joining, if you haven't already. Membership information is here.

image:image.image:title: almont_crop
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Detail of the scanned mylar for the Almont topographic quadrangle. Corner points are highlighted with red boxes, the actual corner of the topo map is in the top left. This would be selected for the initial control point, but the corners would be used in later transforms.

image:image.image:title: Coverage map for PalEON
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The regions with digitized pre-settlement point data are coloured like a creamsicle. The underlying data comes from the US Land Cover Institute and naturalearth (naturalearthdata.com)

image:image.image:title: gaml1007_01
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1: A mentor is a source of knowledge, but must also act as a role model. Wolfgang Laz (pictured in this painting by Guiseppe Arcimbolo) had a reputation for obtaining his library by whatever means necessary, and that reputation lives on. A mentor's reputation lives on through their mentees, so a mentor must consider how their actions may be interpreted.

image:image.image:title: IMG_7455
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Some things to look forward to in the new year.

image:image.image:title: paleon.network
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The network that makes PalEON work. Blue points represent the PIs, linking the vegetation modellers (at the top of the figure), to paleoecologists and statisticians that make up the rest of the team. This was the structure of the team about a year ago.

image:image.image:title: TimePlot
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. How long it takes to plot a data frame increases linearly with the number of rows. Imagine how long it would take if you accidentally plotted all the data in the world!

image:image.image:title: Packrat image from neotomadb.org
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Neotoma project is named after the genus Neotoma, packrats, who collect plant materials to build their middens, that ultimately serve as excellent paleoecological resources, if you're okay sifting through rodent urine.

image:image.image:title: Acquired and Unacquired sites for Neotoma
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Unacquired sites are significantly older than acquired sites in Neotoma, (GLM, gamma family, p < 0.001) with the caveat that unacquired site data is out of date and we adjusted the Neotoma data to account for that (removing all records newer than 1998).

image:image.image:title: Life-Story
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. A two page spread in Life Story for the Mesozoic Era, showing both stylized images of life in the Mesozoic, but also some of the life forms and a time frame for the era.

image:image.image:title: When do I save files?
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Histogram showing the distribution of file timestamps in my 'Documents' directory. Red shading indicates regular work hours.

image:image.image:title: Cover from Souljazz Orchestra's Manifesto album
image:image.image:caption: Fig 1. The Souljazz Orchestra's Manifesto album is not exactly the manifesto we're talking about.

image:image.image:title: NeuroImagingCover
image:image.image:caption: Fig 1. Issue cover for Neuroimage 61(4).

image:image.image:title: Department Faculty and Seminar Sex Ratios
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The relationship between departmental sex ratios and the sex ratios of the seminar series for those departments for the (broadly) Geosciences departments at 16 American universities (listed:here).

image:image.image:title: i120903archie
image:image.image:caption: Today’s Archie may be telling us that in times of idleness we desire business and vice-versa, so that we are never truly at ease; it may be making a larger point that the things we desire will never be as sweet as we imagine; or it may be more specific, showing us that Archie himself cannot stand to spend quiet time with himself without confronting his own essential emptiness. This is pretty heavy stuff, particularly for Reggie, whose own obnoxious egotism has largely shielded him from any kind of depressing introspection. From: The Comics Curmudgeon, September 3, 2012.

image:image.image:title: broken_computer
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Duct tape? Check. Visible wires? Check. Broken plastic? Check. Missing screws? Check. Broken flange thingy? Check. I present to you, a heavily used research grade laptop.

image:image.image:title: Aerial pollen diagram from Vancouver, BC
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The thesis figure that the painting is based on. If youve never seen a stratigraphic diagram before time is on the y axis and each pollen taxon is drawn on a percent basis (the x axis), taxon by taxon.

image:image.image:title: Still life with stratigraphy
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. It's not often you see art inspired by pollen diagrams, but this watercolor shows a figure from my thesis superimposed with flowers and pollen grains, painting by Erica Pratt.

image:image.image:title: Comparisons of oak pollen and other measures
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The comparison of incomparables, and evidence of massive overabundance of oak at Lake Cuitzeo (a percentage of nearly 75,000% reported). This alone would make an excellent paper.

image:image.image:title: Age-depth and stratigraphy of the Lake Cuitzeo core with the purported YDImpact section.
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. This image comes from the Lake Cuitzeo paper, I've highlighted the section that is contested, and I continue to fail to see how a linear trend for 14C dates that were rejected can be simply thrown out.

image:image.image:title: Deposition times for bains in the Neotoma Database from eastern North America through time
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Changes in deposition times over time from the eastern North American dataset, with confidence intervals based on a moving average with a 500 year window.

image:image.image:title: EOF for USHCN precipitation data
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The first axis of a functional Principal Components Analysis (fPCA) ordination of US Historical Climate Network Precipitation data plotted, showing a clear partition of historic precipitation across the Appalachians.

image:image.image:title: LaffGraff
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. I'm just not all that good at making graphs, even when I'm joking about it. What does the y-axis mean really, and if it's proportional to the best graph I can make, why is no point on there at 1.0? Ph.D candidates are all the same, no work ethic!

image:image.image:title: Stand structure in the upper Midwest
image:image.image:caption: Comparing Ramankutty and Foley for the upper Midwest with our estimates of stem density and forest composition.

image:image.image:title: Spreading seaweed
image:image.image:caption: I can't pay to research the effects of fertilizer treatments on crop yields and ecosystem functioning all by myself, but that research directly impacts me! (click for source)

image:image.image:title: One f-th Noise playing some music
image:image.image:caption: Some Ph.D students (now post-docs) working hard at their other job. Rocking.

image:image.image:title: An Experimental Lake
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From the Department of Fisheries and Oceans website, an image of one of the Experimental Lakes in northern Ontario.

image:image.image:title: stormychilcotin
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ecological systems depend on objects that manifest across multiple scales. Macrosystems Ecology seeks to understand ecology at regional to continental scales, which means understanding process at each of these scales.

image:image.image:title: The light pipe!
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Shining a light through flowing water had little economic use for 19th century industry, but it is the basis of billions of dollars of wealth in modern society. (link in french)

image:image.image:title: OpenGovernment Logo
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Open Government initiative was announced by the federal government in 2011.

image:image.image:title: Number of articles and the percentage of articles retracted since 1950 as recorded in Medline.
image:image.image:caption: The number of publications and retractions in the biomedical literature are both increasing, but the rate of retractions is increasing at a faster rate. The large drop in retractions in 2007 in this figure is a result of a lag between publication and retraction.

image:image.image:title: Semi-transparent plot
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. With the addition of the alpha channel it is possible to see that there are regions with much higher densities than others, above and beyond the 'blob' structure. It also makes possible artifacts from the derivation of the climate data visible.

image:image.image:title: Temperature versus Precipitation, opaque
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Annual temperature and summer precipitation for a number of sites in eastern North America. The lack of transparency results in a loss of information about data density when density is very high.

image:image.image:title: extremeGoring
image:image.image:caption: Fig 1. A logo for the proposed ridiculously named project. The lightning bolt symbolizes lightning and the wolf symbolizes a wolf. The map is purely practical.

image:image.image:title: extremeGoring
image:image.image:caption: Fig 1. A possible logo for the proposed project. It looks pretty bad-ass.

image:image.image:title: Fig 1. I want one of these for every vegetation plot in the world!
image:image.image:caption: Fig 1. A phylogeny for a very grassy knoll, recently burned.

image:image.image:title: Figure1.PaleonRegion
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The location of pollen samples sites in the northeastern United States.

image:image.image:title: Predicted GO range under CCSM3a2 using temperature and precipitation
image:image.image:caption: The predicted expansion of Garry Oak range under a CCSMa2 climate scenario using both temperature and precipitation variables. Pellatt et al., 2012

image:image.image:title: Modern and predicted modern extents of Garry oak
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The modern presence/absence of Garry oak, along with the predicted extents using random forest models.

image:image.image:title: Garry Oak suitability and protected areas
image:image.image:caption: Fig 1. The blue represents regions of continuously predicted suitability from the present to 2100.
